original_data.question: A 61-year-old nulliparous woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Her last Pap smear 3 years ago showed atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance. HPV testing was negative at that time. On questioning, she has had fatigue and an increase in abdominal girth despite a 5-kg (11.0-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. She has gastroesophageal reflux disease and Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Menarche was at the age of 10 years and her last menstrual period was 2 years ago. Current medications include omeprazole and levothyroxine. Abdominal examination shows shifting dullness. There is tenderness to palpation of the right lower quadrant but no guarding or rebound. Bimanual palpation shows a small uterus and a right adnexal mass. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

model_response:
The patient has a pelvic mass and adnexal tenderness, which raise concern for ovarian cancer. Her age, however, is more consistent with the diagnosis of endometrial cancer. The history of atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance raises concern for cervical dysplasia. The most common presenting symptoms of endometrial cancer are postmenopausal bleeding and nonmenstrual bleeding. Symptoms of advanced disease include weight loss, abdominal pain, and a change in bowel function. The most common presenting symptom of ovarian cancer is abdominal pain. Physical findings include ascites, a pelvic mass, and tenderness. The most common presenting symptom of cervical cancer is postcoital bleeding. Physical findings include an exophytic mass and cervical dysplasia. The most common presenting symptom of fallopian tube cancer is watery vaginal discharge. Physical findings include a pelvic mass and adnexal tenderness. The most common presenting symptom of vaginal cancer is postmenopausal bleeding. Physical findings include a pelvic mass and vaginal lesions.

Answer: OPTION D IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: A woman with a parity of zero.
Individuals licensed to practice medicine.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
Varying from the norm; not conformable to the type.
A flat, scalelike cell of the skin or mucous membrane

In statistics, a number that expresses the probability that the result of a given experiment or study could have occurred purely by chance. This number can be a margin of error or it can indicate a confidence level.
Testing performed to determine the presence or absence of human papillomavirus in an individual.

An absence finding of the specified component / analyte, organism or clinical sign based on the established threshold of the performed test or procedure.

\[Note: Negative does not necessarily imply the complete absence of the specified item.\]
The dimension of the physical universe which, at a given place, orders the sequence of events. (McGraw-Hill Dictionary of Scientific and Technical Terms, 6th ed)
Used to describe an individual who is unsure of their sexual orientation.
The state of weariness following a period of exertion, mental or physical, characterized by a decreased capacity for work and reduced efficiency to respond to stimuli.
A process of becoming larger, more numerous, more important, or more likely.
That portion of the body that lies between the THORAX and the PELVIS.
Decrease in existing BODY WEIGHT.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
Retrograde flow of gastric juice (GASTRIC ACID) and/or duodenal contents (BILE ACIDS; PANCREATIC JUICE) into the distal ESOPHAGUS, commonly due to incompetence of the LOWER ESOPHAGEAL SPHINCTER.
An autoimmune disorder caused by the production of autoantibodies against thyroid tissue. There is progressive destruction of the thyroid follicles leading to hypothyroidism.
The first MENSTRUAL CYCLE marked by the initiation of MENSTRUATION.
How long something has existed; elapsed time since birth.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.

The periodic shedding of the ENDOMETRIUM and associated menstrual bleeding in the MENSTRUAL CYCLE of humans and primates. Menstruation is due to the decline in circulating PROGESTERONE, and occurs at the late LUTEAL PHASE when LUTEOLYSIS of the CORPUS LUTEUM takes place.

The periodic shedding of the ENDOMETRIUM and associated menstrual bleeding in the MENSTRUAL CYCLE of humans and primates. Menstruation is due to the decline in circulating PROGESTERONE, and occurs at the late LUTEAL PHASE when LUTEOLYSIS of the CORPUS LUTEUM takes place.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
Drugs intended for human or veterinary use, presented in their finished dosage form. Included here are materials used in the preparation and/or formulation of the finished dosage form.

A 4-methoxy-3,5-dimethylpyridyl, 5-methoxybenzimidazole derivative of timoprazole that is used in the therapy of STOMACH ULCERS and ZOLLINGER-ELLISON SYNDROME. The drug inhibits an H(+)-K(+)-EXCHANGING ATPASE which is found in GASTRIC PARIETAL CELLS.

The major hormone derived from the thyroid gland. Thyroxine is synthesized via the iodination of tyrosines (MONOIODOTYROSINE) and the coupling of iodotyrosines (DIIODOTYROSINE) in the THYROGLOBULIN. Thyroxine is released from thyroglobulin by proteolysis and secreted into the blood. Thyroxine is peripherally deiodinated to form TRIIODOTHYRONINE which exerts a broad spectrum of stimulatory effects on cell metabolism.
An assessment of the abdomen including the organs within the abdominal cavity.
A dull achy pain.
Application of fingers with light pressure to the surface of the body to determine consistence of parts beneath in physical diagnosis; includes palpation for determining the outlines of organs.
The region of the abdomen that extends from the median plane to the right of the patient, and from the umbilical plane to the right inguinal ligament.
Relating to, or performed by, both hands.
Application of fingers with light pressure to the surface of the body to determine consistence of parts beneath in physical diagnosis; includes palpation for determining the outlines of organs.
Underdevelopment of the uterus. [HPO:probinson]
An abnormal growth in the ovary, fallopian tube, or surrounding connective tissue.
Systematic, objective appraisal of the significance, effectiveness, and impact of activities or condition according to specified objectives and criteria.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
